publicationstmt.publisher: Digital Collections and Archives, Tufts University

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2021-04-10 19:12:32 -0400.

repository.corpname: Digital Collections and Archives, Tufts University

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is organized into two series: Letters and correspondence, and Research material.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: Martin Green collected these letters from Else von Richthofen. After completing the two books, Professor Green donated the original letters and his research material to Tufts University.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In the course of writing his two books, "The von Richthofen Sisters" (1974), and "The Mountain of Truth" (1986), Tufts University professor Martin Green collected original letters given to him by Else von Richthofen, and secondary material relating to his work studying the Ascona movement.

The principals in the correspondence are Else von Richthofen-Jaffe and Frieda Schloffer-Gross. Else von Richthofen-Jaffe was the sister of Frieda Weekley, wife of the British novelist D.H. Lawrence. Else was born in Metz in 1874 and married Edgar Jaffe, an economist of Max Weber's circle in Heidelberg.

Frieda Schloffer-Gross was the wife of the famous psychoanalyst Otto Gross. She was at one time a student of Sigmund Freud, but later became his adversary. Else, Frieda, Otto Gross, and a number of others mentioned in the letters were part of a larger movement in early twentieth-century Europe that advocated a return to "nature." They participated in the creation of what is now known as "modern" thought and culture.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Elisabeth Helene Amalie Sophie Freiin (Baroness) von Richthofen (also known as Else Jaffé) was born in Château-Salins, France on October 8, 1874. Her parents were Friedrich Ernst Emil Ludwig Freiherr von Richthofen (1844-1915), an engineer in the German army, and Anna Elise Lydia Marquier (1852-1930).

Although Else von Richthofen first worked as a teacher, she earned her doctorate in economics from Heidelberg University in 1901 and started work as a labor inspector in Karlsruhe. She married Edgar Jaffé (1865-1921), a well-known economist and entrepreneur, in 1902. After Jaffé bought the journal Archiv für Sozialwissenschaft und Sozialpolitik, his former professor, Max Weber, became one of its editors. With Jaffé, Else had three children, Friedel (born 1903), Marianne (born 1905) and Hans (born 1909).

Else became acquainted with intellectuals and authors, including the psychoanalyst Otto Gross (with whom she had a fourth child, Peter), the writer Fanny zu Reventlow, and others. She also had affairs with her former professor Max Weber and his brother Alfred Weber with whom she later lived for several years after her husband died.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Some material in this collection may be protected by copyright and other rights. Please see "Reproductions and Use" on the Digital Collections and Archives website for more information about reproductions and permission to publish.
Any intellectual property rights that the donor possesses have been transferred to Tufts University.

physdesc.extent: Each transcript has two versions - one in PDF and the other in MS Word.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Original letters and correspondence given to Martin Green by Else von Richthofen-Jaffe. Most have been written between 1900 and 1915. The bulk of the material is letters to Else from Frieda Schloffer-Gross. These letters are item-level cataloged, and have summaries in English. Some letters, principally from Otto Gross also have English summaries. Other letters, from Otto Gross and others, have not been summarized. The letters were not in order when they were received by Professor Green. An attempt has been made to reconstruct the original order of the letters, but some documents are clearly fragments of longer letters and their original order has been lost. There are typescripts (in German) of 45 of the letters (items 45-90) to Else von Richthofen.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged numerically by Professor Green's numbering system.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: She tells about a recent move to a new place. She mentions Hickson, who is in the process of writing a book. Seems to be in a melancholic and confused mood about herself and the future.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter is a fragment. Discusses her relationship with Hickson whom she is very fond of and whose character she admires. Expresses concern that Else will throw herself completely into her work and will neglect "the duties of love" which she calls the "crown of feminine life." Expects the future to be difficult for herself.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Frieda expresses her surprise and joy about Else receiving her doctorate after six semesters.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: She seems depressed and full of melancholy. Refers to problems with her leg which her physicians attribute to her bad nerves. She takes arsenic and receives electro-shock therapy for her neurosis. Considers Else as her only trusted friend. She feels her neurosis is related to her hysterical mother.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: After she recuperated in Abbazia her emotional and physical suffering has returned. Hickson seems to hold back-offers no commitment, nothing tangible which is distressing her.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Fragment. Mentions expected arrival of a new child-a sibling for Gerti. Arnold is the father. The date is written in a different writing on back of the letter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: She talks about the upcoming Christmas holidays which everyone expects to celebrate with family and friends. It is not clear if the letter is a fragment.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This is a response to a letter from Else. She alludes to someone who is not necessarily an angel. Post card.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: [Frieda] seems happy and jealous about a serious relationship Else is having and encourages her to get married. She is nostalgic about the "blossoms of love" that existed between them. Letter is fragment.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Frieda refers to an event in Else's life which she finds hard to believe [possibly the dissolution of a relationship with a man]. Frieda states her undying love and support for Else and how she was not really able to share in Else's previous happiness.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Frieda is inquiring on behalf of a friend who seperated from her husband about living arrangements for single women who plan to study in Karlsruhe. Post card.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: She is very philosophical about the ups and downs of life. She is positive about the idea of marriage.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: She makes plans for a visit with Else. She mentions a man, whom she describes as an idealist and who does not fit the times and the Graz social scene. She met him during a musical gathering-she herself enjoys playing the piano. Letter is a fragment.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: She is clarifying her travel plans for visiting Else. She declares her need for an object of "active affection" and asks Else if she wanted to be it.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: She is worn out from the many obligations, especially towards other people and is looking forward to her visit with Else.

did.unittitle: refers to herself as the Blonde woman [Frieda Gross] to Bethel (Else von Richtofen]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Frieda expresses her gratitude for Else's understanding. She reports on a visit in Stuttgart with a wealthy family, where she observed how the young wife was losing her individuality under the influence of her husband. Tells about her experience at the "Institution Hessing" for crippled people. Frieda escorted Aunt Sofie to this place.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: [Frieda] describes her experience at the "Institute Hessing" where she is staying as Aunt Sofie's companion. She is observing the suffering of the crippled people who are seeking a cure with the help of Hessing's modern therapeutic exercise equipment. Hessing, the owner of the clinic, is making sexual advances to most women patients. The patients are from all over the world. Letter is a fragment.

did.unittitle: refers to herself as your women [Frieda Gross] to Bethel [Else von Richtofen]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: [Frieda] considers Aunt Sofie's decision to interrupt her "cure", her stay at the rehabilitation clinic as a mistake and blames "him" [possibly Aunt Sofie's husband] for this decision.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Reports from a sailing vacation in the South where she enjoys the beauty of nature in the company of her father. She dreads the return to Graz [her home] and wishes to work there with old and sick people and children.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Friedel is full of amiration for Else doing her lecture tour. Feels her own life is trivial-has desire to experience life. She feels the same attachment to Else and likens it to the feeling for a husband.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: She tells of the love and tender feelings she has for Else. Expresses disappointment about not receiving a Christmas card from Hickson. She talks of her "intensive" correspondence with Smith, a young American who is crippled and who seems to develop an affection for her. Letter is a fragment.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Friedel states her personal impressions and feelings about Hermann who seems to be in the process of becoming a professor. She finds her nursing classes very interesting.

did.unittitle: Sofie [Riehl, Frieda Gross' Aunt] to Elisabeth [Else von Richtofen ?]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sofie tells about her enjoyable Spring vacation in Eisnach. Contemplates Friedel's [Frieda Gross] future in the nursing field. Emphasizes Friedel's love for mankind. Feels a visit to berlin where social efforts are being implemented would be of interest. Urges Elisabeth to read the true idealism in "Memoirs of a Revolutionary" by Krapotkin.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Friedel asks Bethel about her opinion of a man who is involved in a love triangle and who is dishonest about it towards one of the women. This man feels the need to conquer her [Frieda Gross] even though she is unsure about her feelings and the entire situation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter is a fragment. Friedel relates a story about a couple who is deeply in love, but he does not want to marry her because of the age difference. Both are suffering terribly and Friedel finds the situation crazy. Friedel is happiest in the company of women and does not think she will get married. She wants to do social work.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Friedel [Frieda Gross] expresses her happiness about Else's engagement. States that the beauty of life can only be enjoyed as a couple. Tells of her own wonderful relationship with Otto Gross which just happened. People of Graz think he is crazy and her parents adopted a resigned attitude toward him. She hopes to harmonize reality and the ideal in his character. She calls him a genius.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter is a fragment. Relates Aunt Mili's thoughts that Else should have worked for a few more years as a factory inspector before getting married. Otto [Gross] her loved one, seems to be not well liked. Frieda states that every human being can fullfill their potential in association with another person.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This is a response to Else's engagement. Frieda hopes this will not change anything in her close relationship with Else. Frieda writes about her intense love for Otto [Gross] and her happiness, but she also states he is not very supportive. The social relationships that Frieda feels obligated to are called lies by Otto. Only Frieda's father and her uncle Lusso seem to be accepting of her relationship with Otto.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Frieda states she found a home in her love to Otto [Gross], points out the parallels in her and Else's life. She talks about a previous love to Hickson, whom she feared at times. She describes Otto's ideas about love and the true woman and refers to him as a genius who is often misunderstood. However there is a terrible aspect to his life-the morphine addiction-which he tried to overcome in a rehabilitation program. She thinks this will improve when they are married.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Frieda reflects about her upcoming wedding to Otto Gross on February 23. She and Otto consider it a sacrifice to the conventions of society and to the relatives. She is looking forward to her new life with Otto. She calls it home. They will live in Otto's parents' vacation villa. Their reading list for the honeymoon is "Zarathustra, Riehl's Philosophy of the present times, a volume of Psychiatry".

did.unittitle: Friedel [Frieda Gross-Schloffer] to Bethel [Else von Richthofen]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Frieda reflects on the happy times she spent with Else in her youth. Compares Else to the men in her life, who were not as important. Tells about her daily life with Otto Gross who is an assistant at the clinic. Calls him her reason for being, her great love, but she states that he acts like an ill mannered boy occasionally.

did.unittitle: Friedel [Frieda Gross-Schloffer] to Bethel [Else von Richthofen]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Frieda talks about the details of her planned visit to Else.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Postcard - Handwriting is in an archaic German.

did.unittitle: Friedel [Frieda Gross-Schloffer] to Bethel [Else von Richthofen]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Frieda Gross is lonely while Otto Gross is travelling in Macedonia. She tries to figure out how a visit with Else can be arranged.

did.unittitle: Friedel [Frieda Gross-Schloffer] to Bethel [Else von Richthofen]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Frieda is reminiscing about her youth. She talks about the intense feeling of love and admiration she had for Else. She tells about Otto's unhappiness due to lack of intellectual stimulation, lack of friends in Graz. Otto finally received the position of assistant professor. He is disappointed about the long wait. Frieda feels guilty about her obsessive concern for her father and fears neglecting Otto. She enjoys discussing psychology with Otto.

did.unittitle: Friedel [Frieda Gross-Schloffer] to Bethel [Else von Richthofen]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Frieda states that she is happy about the happiness [the sexual affair] Otto is experiencing with Else. This won't affect her own love to Else whom she probably loves more than any man. She refers to Otto as "our boy." The worries about him are exhausting for her and the separation from him is a welcome break. She tells about money problems. She wants Otto's old suit for Erich Muhsam. [This letter is possibly a fragment.]

did.unittitle: Friedel [Frieda Gross-Schloffer] to Bethel [Else von Richthofen]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Frieda agreed to a pact with Otto that gives him absolute freedom. She seems disappointed, resigned, and bitter about her relationship with Otto. She considered the idea of drowning herself but refrained from it because of her child Peterle. Otto displays psychotic behaviour. He doesn't change his clothes for days, doesn't wash himself until he is "healed" from what he calls "Freudian symptoms." Frieda tries not to get emotionally involved. Otto spends most of his time with Muhsam, Frank, and Benz [Sophie?].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This is only an empty envelope.

did.unittitle: Friedel [Frieda Gross-Schloffer] to Bethel [Else von Richthofen]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Frieda relates instructions regarding corrections for a book to be published at Vogel in Leipzig. This message is for Otto who seems to be staying with Else. She mentions Otto's presentation in Amsterdam about "secondary functions." [Letter is a fragment.]

did.unittitle: Friedel [Frieda Gross-Schloffer] to Else [Else von Richthofen]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Frieda tells about the shock and sadness she felt about "their affair." [This might refer to Else's and Otto's relationship.] She talks about the pain it causes her to see Else's affiliation with a person who hates Otto [possibly Max Weber]. She talks about an upcoming convention in Amsterdam she plans to attend with Otto. She expresses her gratitude to Else for personal favors, especially caring for Peterle, her son.

did.unittitle: Friedel [Frieda Gross-Schloffer] to Else [Else von Richthofen]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Frieda discusses Peterle's (her infant son) care at Else's home [during the time Frieda plans to travel with Otto to Amsterdam]. She reports that Otto is trying to quit his morphine addiction. She talks about loneliness and refers to her infant son as her only friend in life. States her mission in life is to spread good will.

did.unittitle: Friedel [Frieda Gross-Schloffer] to Bethel [Else von Richthofen]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Frieda seems in a resigned mood because she lost the child she expected. She is not doing well physically either. She wants another child with Ernst with whom she shares an "unfortunate" love. Compares the two men Otto and Ernst, who made her life equally difficult. Called Otto's character corrupted by drugs and describes Ernst as sad, suffering, and idealistic. Otto and Ernst are working together at the Adriatic Coast and Freida fears it will end badly. Frieda reiterates her affection for Else and tries to view the future positively. Calls a woman named Lang a hysterical cow.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Fragment. Frieda asks existential question about her life and expresses fear about her own and her boys' future. Sofie is expecting a child which Otto acknowledges as his own. Frieda mentions she is spending 70 Marks for Sofie to have the child. She feels guilty about the hysteria that surrounds the child and calls the situation disgusting. Frieda mentions Adele's statement after Peter's birth, that they would emigrate to America if "such a thing" would happen again. [Letter is a fragment and has two ink spots.]

did.unittitle: Friedl [Frieda Gross-Schloffer] to "Love of my heart" [Else von Richthofen]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Frieda states how much Else is in her thoughts. She is like the everlasting light in an environment which she calls mostly gloomy. She refers to the fragile state of her own health. She enoys her English courses at the university. In general she is disappointed in herself and what she achieved in life.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Fragment of a letter. Subjects: her relationship with probably Otto Gross; discusses her individuals, special status in his life, in contrast to other women in his life.Compares her children, Eva-Verena and Peter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subjects: Relationship with Ernst [probably Frick] She has a resigned attitude toward him. She describes her children Eva Verena, the baby, whose father is Ernst [Frick] and Peter [Father Otto Gross] who has significant mood changes. Her father dies in Graz.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subjects: Fredel is upset about suicide notice of Sofie [Benz] (out of newspaper). Questions the extent of responsibility of Otto Gross' involvement in death. Comments on Sofie's and Otto's personalities, which both share mental illness. Ernst [Frick] is angry about the incident with Sofie and Otto-- Fredel pities Otto, but is disdainful of him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subject: Describes relationship with Ernst [Frick] whom she calls sick. She is disillusioned and resigned about this relationship. She met with Otto [Gross] during his drug rehabilitation and is very pessimistic about him returning to his old addictive pattern soon. She talks about her own daily struggle with life.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subject: Reaction to an illness of Else's and description of the strong friendship between them. Fredel's hunger for love. Fredel is pregnant again...her life is quite restless; she hopes this child [of Ernst Frick's] will help her relationship with Ernst, unhappy Love. Another visit of Fredel's with Otto, whom she describes as strangely healthy, yet unbearable. He wants to see her again. Request for money for Ernst's trip to England.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subject: Letter is a fragment; she asks Else for 3000 mark but does not want to disclose the purpose of the loan.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subject: Letter is a fragment; After receiving money from Else... Fredel has lost her unborn child, she thanks Else [Bethel] for her support during this tough time. She discloses that Ernst has left her for England to be with Friedele and claims not to be jealous. sentimental and melancholic mood.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subject: She is talking about vacation plans with Frick to visit Lake Geneva.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subject: Letter from Ernst Frick to Else, to be forwarded to Fredele [Gross] whom he has not been able to contact yet. Subject: travels to england. (Cafe Restaurant Americain Stationary)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subject: Freda is in a very bad emotional state, feeling life is senseless and she also feel that Ernst is losing strength as his trial draws near. There is an upcoming trial mentioned, probably the one for Ernst Frick. Freda does not know if she wants to attend it. Love makes life worth living. Mentions how aspects of life are to be perceived: happiness and despair are dual aspects of life. financial difficulties for Freda because of trial. looks forward to being with Ernst again but worries about the future. asks for books to keep Ernst company in jail.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subject: [Frieda] is pessimistic about her life and feels emotional pain. Mentions Alfred [Weber] and the children as Else's reason for happiness. talks about her emotional difficulties about an upcoming 2nd trial. asks for a temporary loan from Else to pay Dr. Skarvan MD of Bat. Austria, doesn't disclose the reason.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subject: Letter is a fragment. Expresses gratitude for the dresses which she received as a gift [for her daughter]. wants to get more information from Else about the developments that Friedele [V.R.] told her husband about her relation to Otto [Gross] and Ernst [Frick]. Is fatalistic about her own life.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subject: He does not want to see her while he is imprisoned. He occupies himself by contemplating essential ideas of life, like freedom. States that culture is decadent.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter is a fragment. Subject: Thinks her mail is being opened--possibly involvements of the police. Talks about Brennwald, the attorneys whom she describes as money hungry and lazy and not informed about details of Ernst's case. Chances for a good outcome of Ernst's trial are slim, according to her. Mentions Paul's release from custody. Talks about Friedele's new love: Lawrence and wants to find out more about him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subject: Tells what is going on with Ernst's trial. Feels that the court has some animosity toward Ernst and considers it unfair that they don't release him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subject: Tells Else of her fondness of her. Ernst has been released from prison and has a hard time adjusting. Days later, Ernst has been arrested again for possession of explosives. She is in love with him again.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subject: Expresses the wish Else would visit her. Talks about her children and how she is even more in love with Ernst. Is sorry she can't meet with Emil Lask [Heidelberg Philosopher].

did.unittitle: Friedel [Frieda Gross] to Bethel [Else von Richthofen].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter is a fragment. Subject: She thanks her for the money and the telegram. Tells that she hates Otto [Gross] and expects horrible things from him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subject: States, it would be dangerous for Otto to come to Switzerland, since the authorities would pick him up. She feels adversarial toward him, but doesn't want to have him as an enemy. In her imagination she is always expecting Ernst to show up. Concerns about the situation regarding the children.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter is a fragment. Subject: She talks about her relationship with Ernst which depresses her and whom she hates now. Wants to borrow 5000 mark from Else for living expenses. Talks about having to give up the children. Tells of her nightmares and emotional state of panic.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter is a fragment. Subject: States that it is shortly before a trial (unclear whose trial, possibly about losing their children.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter is a fragment. Subject: She is looking forward to a restful vacation in the mountains. Expects a visit from Else. Talks about Else's unfounded jealousy with respect to herself and Max Weber.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subject: She is overwhelmed by fear and feels that she is almost losing her mind. She talks about a person named Pellech (her lawyer) and a trial (concerning the children) that is coming to a close. Talks about her attitude toward life: her love to Peter [son] and Ernst [lover] and her suffering and feeling of depression. Fears Ernst could be leaving her.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subject: Expresses her compassion about the death of Else's son, Peter. She wants to come and comfort Else.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subject: Frieda wants to come and visit Else to comfort her [Else is in mourning about the loss of her son, Peter.] Talks to Otto [Gross] request for a divorce since he wants to get married again. Mentions her reservations about Otto's character.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subject: Frieda and her children have been ill and she can't come home for a visit therefore. Talks about the profound effect Peter's death had on her.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subject: She feels she couldn't write so much nonsense, since it is all due to the fact that she cannot master her life. Update on her family life. Talks about Else not living in Wolfratshausen anymore.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subject: Talks about her ideas about death in connection with Peter's death. Reflects on her life's changes and now she has to do all the house work herself, which tires her out. Mentions Else living in "Vogelnest" now (translated "Bird's nest").

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subject: States that she doesn't have the strength to cope with daily life. She is exhausted and her nerves are ruined. Wants to know what's going on with Else.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subject: She thanks Else for her and Max Weber's financial help. States that her emotional pain and melancholy is a serious illness. Refers to Edgar [Jaffe] who seems to be hospitalized for the same illness. She was away for some rest and recooperation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter is a fragment. Subject: Informs Else of Otto [Gross'] death of pneumonia in Berlin. States, something big has come to a close without a solution (referring to Otto). Talks about financial troubles. Emphasizes that she is Peter Gross' guardian.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subject: States she had a nervous breakdown because of jealousy--probably because of Margarethe (Fellerer) whom she calls the devil's bride. Mentions Peter Wyneken as a possible way out of her problems. (Wyneken Operates an Experimental School.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subject: She Thanks Else for gift of money. Mentions a Mrs von Strzgowsky from Graz, she is wealthy and full of vitality-- she left her husband and 6 children to live with an old friend of Otto [Gross]. Ernst whom she calls a failure in real life but "good like" is now a lover of Margarethe. She considers him a pathological case.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subject: Friedel considers her life and her relationship with Ernst [Frick] sad and almost desperate. Calls him paranoid. His attitude is very negative toward her. But she knows that she has strength to survive. Talks about the personality of her children.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subject: Frieda feels isolated-- her focus are only the children. Ernst eager to move to Arbe, Tyrol, an isolated island in Yugoslavia?--thinks it is better for him as a painter. [Heinrich] Goesch wants to come also. Frieda concerned about practical aspects of new life and schooling of children.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Dark stains on paper. Subject: Frieda's relationship with Ernst is bad. He is hateful and paranoid toward her. She is trying to come to terms with this situation. Cornelia, her daughter, is very ill.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subject: They found out that Cornelia (daughter) has Tuberculosis. Friedel writes about her love and fear for this child.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subject: Frieda is hopeful about Cornelia's prognosis regarding her tuberculosis. She is emotionally and physically exhausted. Feels her situation with Ernst [Frick] cannot be solved.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subject: Mentions (Edgar) Salin. Refers to Klages' writings with the title "Essence of Conciousness". She thinks they are more interesting than Jasper's. Talks about Miss Walther's ideas about phenomenalism.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subject: Friedel feels she is losing her identity because of Ernst's (Frick) tyrannical and fanatical behavior. Her love is dead. Relief that Ernst has left for Germany. Feels this disharmony is bad for the children. Refers to the difficult financial situation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subject: Friedel tells about miserable living conditions in Ascona--she converted a stable into an apartment. She feels Ernst hates her and destroys her life. She longs for a visit with Else.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subject: Refers to a possible marriage between Ernst [Frick] and Margarethe. She fears he would want to take the children from her claiming that she is intellectually and morally unfit to be a mother. States that Ernst made her life miserable.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subject: Refers to her emotional suffering that manifests itself physically. Refers to some financial support from her brothers. Feels Else's relationship with Alfred is very fortunate.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subject: Friedel is concerned about her son's (Peter's) health. He is in Else's care and she is grateful. Refers to meeting Marianne Weber and is impressed with her self assurance and her sense of unity.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subject: Talks about her childrens' life and her own emotional state, which seems in harmony with nature.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subject: Concerned about Peter's and Eva's health (possibly tuberculosis). Talks about her and Else's common part. books are her only relief from her anxieties.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Note: Blue ink stains on both sheets. Subject: She talks about her philosophy of life and the importance of the right attitude toward it. Great concern about Peter's health. The other children are helping to support him even though they are hardly getting by themselves.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subject: Talks about her mother being very ill and how all the children and Ernst [Frick] are caring for her. Praises her mother.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subject: Reminisces about her admiration and gratitude and love for Else. Peter her son is a physician now.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subject: Speaks about her own life in a melancholic way. Prays for a peaceful death. Refers to her children's life as hard and sad. She lost her house in Bosco and lives in a rooming house. Talks about her loneliness and hopelessness despite Limsero (a man).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Subject: Refers to her children Peter and Cornelia-- both are very sick (possibly tuberculosis).

did.unittitle: Friedl [Frieda Gross] to Bethel [Else von Richthofen]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter is a fragment. Frieda expresses her love for Else. She talks about the dilemma between her passion for life and her lack of physical strength. Her "sciatic leg" is being treated with arsenic and iron. Mentions a relationship with Rupprecht which she views as real, good, adna lasting.

did.unittitle: Friedl [Frieda Gross] to Bethel [Else von Richthofen]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In this letter Frieda states her enormous suffering due to her "neuralgic leg." The pain is unbearable in spite of the medication (morphine, chloroform, bromine, and electroshocks). Else seems to be a beacon of happiness in her life. She refers to herself as a spiritual and physical cripple, no longer human.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter is a fragment. She states that Tyrol is becoming a Goggingen for her. She mentions her enduring love for the factory inspector [Else] and talks about trivial things.

did.unittitle: Friedl [Frieda Gross] to Bethel [Else von Richthofen], March 21

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Fragment. Frieda refers to the terrible news about Schlussar and how we seem to worry about trivialities. She announces that they are moving to Glacisstrasse, an elegant apartment. She is looking forward to playing her new piano there. [Correspondence Frieda Gross - Else von Richthofen continues with #200]

did.unittitle: Otto Gross to Else von Richthofen

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: He talks about their fragile friendship - their happiness was perfect in the past. He is concerned her feelings for him have changed and wants a truthful basis between them. He mentions a surgeon as a possible rival [this refers to Volcker]. He talks about the social class system. He is waiting for her call if she still has the same feelings for him. [1 sheet partially torn.]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: He is concerned about her silence and worries about her feelings for him. He distances himself from Schiemann who asked Edgar (Else's husband) for money.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: He mentions that he is involved in a rehab program [probably regarding his drug addiction] and he asks for her love and support. He hopes to get together as soon as he has improved.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: He tells how enraptured he was about her phone call and how he could feel her presence. He contrasts he friendship and dependability with the unreliability of passion. He talks about his ideas of eroticism.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: He considers her letter as a document of her love to him. He refers to the wonderful times they enjoyed at the country house. Describes the strength and pefection of their love, since she does not object to him loving her sister as well.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: He talks with melancholy about their love and happiness. How perfect they were and their transitory aspects. He feels he will always be tied to her. [Second page torn.]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: He talks about his great love for her and the positive influence her love had on his life and work. He has moved on beyond Nietzsche and Freud. She gave him confidence and energy with her trusting love to overcome his resignation. Iriedel [Frieda Weekley] has given him joyful hope as well. No date available

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Refers to M. [probably Muhsam, friend of Otto Gross and lover of Frieda Gross] with whom he got together at the [Cafe] Stephanie. Otto mentions that some matter with M. have come to a close. [Postcard.]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Otto expresses his concern for Else and mentions his big hope [probably their child that Else is expecting.] Mentions Frieda [Gross] who has just given birth and who is with M. (Muhsam her lover). States he doesn't believe in complete happiness.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: She criticizes his attitude toward women who love him - referring to Frieda Gross. He does not see them as individuals but only wants followers of his teachings. She claims that his productivity and judgment may have suffered from his morphine addiction.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter is a fragment (page 6 of a missing letter). He is referring to the possibility of Edgar [Jaffe's] love to Else coming to an end, since he feels that Edgar was incompatible with Else. This implies more hope for their own love. No date available

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Hanns (Otto's father) is asking Otto to edit a paper of his and gives instructions about the format. No date available

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Postcard (that someone has scribbled over). She talks about being with Muhsam instead of Peterle on this day.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A congratulatory note to Else [v. R] on earning her doctorate in Heidelberg. (language is English)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: He talks about his love and happiness with Freida [Weekly, his wife] and how he admires the nobility of her character. (language is English)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: He praises Else's achievements in her new post for the government of Baden. Mentions his new born son. Invites her for a visit to Nottingham. (language is English)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: She mentions a common acquaintance named Goldsmith whom Else has met [recently]. She talks about her happy family life. Encourages Else to continue her work after she is married. No date available

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: She tells Else [her sister] that she feels great respect for her. She expects Else's lifestyle to be grand and that she will be wealthy. Mentions a person named Moubart. No date available

did.unittitle: Freiderike [Freida Von Richthofen] to Else [Von Richthofen]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: She talks about family and social matters. She feels the need for help with the care of her baby since she considers herself ignorant about it. Asks Else to purchase an appliance [burner, heater ?] for her. No date available

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Mentions Behling, who is in love. Luisa and Johanna are involved in the situation. Mention M. who loves her. Explains her relationship with Kurth-feels superior to him. States ahe was always true to herself in her emotions and has no guilty feelings. No date available

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Refers to Behling's relationship with Hannele. Freida finds the secrecy that surrounds it distasteful. Mentions that her health is not too good. Had dinner alone with M. Rohr -- felt uncomfortable about it.

did.unittitle: Fritzle [Freida Von Richthofen ?] to Else [Von Richthofen]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Mentions Helene and Karoline who visited her. She doesn't believe in her own infallible virtue anymore, since the affair with Kammacher. States her fondness for her sister, who will be visiting Graz.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Edgar is relating Otto [Gross's] query regarding a possible change of Else's feelings toward Otto. Otto wants to know if this was related to Else's experience with V. [Volcker ?] or a result of her naturaal inclination toward a principle that is hostile toward him. Edgar suspects that Else has other reasons. No date available

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Friedel is inquiring about Else's life during these difficult times of war. She expresses her own feelings about the war and dying

did.unittitle: Freida [Von Richthofen] to her mother [Von Richthofen]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Reports that Ernst, her husband is ill caused by his big, bad nerves. Tells about the good times and good relationship she has had with her mother-in-law Weekly. Refers to a certain (possibly questionable) behavior by her sister-in-law Edith, who is acting like "Boll". No date available

did.unittitle: Sofie [Riehl] her aunt to Freidl [Freida Gross]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: She talks about her love for Freida and that she cannot yet disclose the reasons for not writing.

did.unittitle: Sofie [Riehl] her aunt to Freidl [Freida Gross]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: She is relating her grief about Helene's death and begs Freida not to disclose anything about Helene as a person. She talks about moving to Berlin and vacationing at a resort on the Kaltic Sea. She mentions Lasso (family member?) and the Brooks (family friends). Tells her how much she needs her. [black edging on stationary]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In spirit Freida is sharing her thoughts with Else and she wishes they could be together. She talks about the baptism of Arnold, Friedrich, Ernst. Calls Munich a blessed city and feels Graz is dreadful. [This is a continuation of the correspondence Frieda Gross to Else Von Richthofen. It joins up with #99]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Fragment. Frieda states that the music of "Tristan" [by Wagner] and Beethoven are one of life's best experiences. They are some of the few things making life worthwhile. She sees herself as remaining the same, never getting old and perhaps never mature.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Fragment. She talks about friends, wants to keep her relationships with Rupprecht as a father-daughter type. She mentions Hickson who will publish in a philosophical journal. She talks about the concern for her father's well-being. Her daily routine is practicing piano, studying philosophy and caring for the poor.

did.unittitle: Friedl [Frieda Gross] to Bethel [Else Von Richthofen].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Fragment. Frieda is referring to someone whom she is very fond of and has a terminal illness. He will return to America [Smith ?] and probably will forget her quickly if he should get better.

did.unittitle: Friedl [Frieda Gross] to Bethel [Else Von Richthofen]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Fragment. Frieda is very happy, but only Else is supposed to know about the reasons for it. She states her life is "immersed in gold" [could imply her enormous happiness]. She expresses her joy and wants to know more.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: [Copy of an autobiographical statement by Else Von Richthofen] An autobigraphical summary of important periods and events in Else Von Richthofen's life and the people who are connected with them. Changing relationship with husband Edgar Jaffe from the feeling of protection to disappointment. Relationship with Volcker, her physician. Relationship with Otto Gross--his teachings of erotic freedom and the effect it had. Met Max and Marianne Weber through childhood friend Frieda Gross. Enduring relationship with Alfred Weber, brother of Max Weber, whom she viewed as possessive and coercive at times.

did.unittitle: Marianne Weber to Else von Richthofen in German script

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Eleven letters from Marianne Weber to Else von Richthofen in German script.

physdesc.extent: Each transcript has two versions - one in Word and the other in PDF.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Transcription of von Richthofen correspondence provided by Frieda Schlofer, November 2007, on electronic media.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Material collected by Tufts University professor Martin Green for research in writing the two books "The Mountain of Truth" and "The von Richthofen Sisters." The research material contains copies of letters, articles and photographs related to the Ascona (Switzerland) movement. Ascona was the center for "New Age" activities in the early part of the twentieth century. There are also letters from Hermann Muller, a German scholar, concerning Muller's work on Gusto Groser, the "nature man," and his influence on Hesse, the German novelist. There are also copies of letters from the influential German dance instructor Rudolf von Laban to Brandenberg. In addition, there are copies of essays by the criminologist Hanns Gross (father of Otto Gross), Alfred Weber, Nohl, and letters related to variious Ascona personalities, including Lisa Ullmann and the Perrottet family. Finally, there are copies of articles by and about Otto Gross and a program from the Ascona Festival of 1978.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged as found.

did.unittitle: The Ascona File, The Muller letter
The Ascona File, The Muller letter
The Ascona File, The Muller letter
The Ascona File, The Muller letter
The Ascona File, The Muller letters and essays on Hensseby Graser and Blatter about Lusto Graser [student in Munich studied Gusto Grosser (in German)]
The Ascona File, Theater Pamphlets and Pictures
The Ascona File, Otto Gross's Work and Articles about Otto Gross
The Ascona File, Otto Gross : Published Essays
The Ascona File, Program etc. of 1978 Ascona Festival, photograph/ photocopy (in German)
Rudolf Laban to Hans Brandenburg (in German). The Ascona File: copies from the Stad.bib Munich
The Ascona File, Replies to various letters of Inquiry to various archives/ Freida's Essay on Schiller/ Else's Interview with Lois Hoffman
The Ascona File, Letters from (not by) Muller
The Ascona File, Ida Oedankover: 2 essays/reviews of Zunada Omeuda (a props (tracer)), Postcards from Szeeman/ Essay by Nohl, Essay by Alfred Weber
The Ascona File, Letters Relative to Laban: from Lisa Ullmann and the Perottet Family, Letters from September to December
